awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multiphase magnetohydrodynamic mixing models for liquid metal battery applications
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Kelley, Douglas 
Proposal Number: 1552182

The goal of this CAREER proposal is to explore the fluid dynamics effects that are important in the performance of batteries that utilize liquid metals as electrodes. Such batteries hold a strong promise for energy storage applications on an electrical grid with intermittent energy sources, such as one based on renewable energy sources. The PI proposes to use alloys that are liquid at lower temperatures (at about 160C) instead of currently applied options, where operations at temperatures in the range of 550C are used. 

The battery behavior is viewed from the transport phenomena point of view, where fluid flow, mass and heat transfer are limiting the battery performance. Prior work has focused on materials and chemistry. In a liquid metal battery, fluid flow brings reactants about 10 mm to the interface where primary reactions charge and discharge the battery, removes reacted material, and prevents the formation of undesirable solids. The questions to be addressed in this work include: Which boundary layer - viscous, thermal, or electromagnetic - mediates mass transport? How does flow affect growth and erosion of solid phases? How do solid phases affect flow? How do size and aspect ratio affect the relationship between inputs and outputs? How does the mass transfer rate depend on temperature difference and current density?
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
One overarching question drove this integrated research and education project: How does fluid flow affect the performance of liquid metal batteries? Liquid metal batteries are a new technology being brought to market for storing large amounts of energy on electrical grids, making intermittent wind and solar power far more useful. But a liquid battery subjected to large electrical currents and high temperatures certainly involves fluid flow. Understanding the effects of that flow required studying fundamental and largely unknown flow interactions with currents, temperatures, and chemical reactions. We combined experiments and simulations to study the problem. We designed and built new laboratory devices to model liquid metal batteries, with precise control of temperature and current. Our experiments used low-temperature liquid metals like lead-bismuth (similar to common solder) and gallium to allow rich measurements. We found that flows are organized by specific motions including jump rope vortices, torsional modes, and swirl flow. We characterized new electrolyte materials for liquid metal batteries and improved ultrasound methods for measuring flow of liquid metals. We built a numerical model to predict the combined effects of flow and diffusion of reacting materials. We wrote the leading review article in the field. Studying the stability of liquid metal batteries led us to invent a new method for stabilizing aluminum production cells, which are susceptible to some of the same problems. Our invention works by adding an oscillating component to the steady electrical current that runs through the aluminum cell, and in simulations, it significantly reduces energy use and carbon footprint. This project supported the scientific training of one postdoc, three PhD students, and many undergraduate researchers. This project supported public outreach talks from leading scientists and entrepreneurs working on alternative energy and fluid dynamics. As part of this project, we also taught hands-on engineering courses for at-risk high school students.


Last Modified: 05/20/2022
Modified by: Douglas H Kelley
